Fig 7 Fig. 8 XPS spectra of (a) Full survey scan (b) Si 2p (c) O 1s (d) Ni 3p/Al 2p and (e) Sr 3d and (f) Ni 2p core level of Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst. Fig 8 Fig. 9 Compendium of comparison of catalysts reported in the literature and prepared Ni/Sr-ZSM-5. Selectivity of ethylene (a) and ethanol conversion (b) at relative temperature difference. ΔT ( °C) corresponds to the difference between our operation temperature (i.e., 250 °C) and the temperature reported in the respective literature. All the above literature has been tabulated in Table S1. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Effect of (a) temperature and (b) WHSV on ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity. Reaction conditions: catalyst = 2 g, feed conc. = 6%, WHSV = 6 h−1, N2 flow = 10 mL min−1, pressure = 1 atm, TOS = 5 h. Fig 10 Fig. 11 Rate of formation of ethylene over H-ZSM-5 and Ni/Sr-ZSM-5. Reaction conditions: catalyst = 2 g, feed conc. = 6%, temp. = 250 °C, WHSV = 9 h−1, N2 flow = 10 mL min−1, pressure = 1 atm. Fig 11 Fig. 12 TOS study using Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst. Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst was synthesized with tuned acidity and improved hydrothermal stability desired for the dehydration of dilute ethanol. Operating conditions were established to maximize the ethylene selectivity from ethanol dehydration by controlling side reactions, using 6% aqueous ethanol as a model feedstock for fermenter broth. Detailed characterization data of the catalyst reveals that Ni in the catalyst is responsible for the enhanced, near quantitative ethylene selectivity at optimum reaction conditions (temperature of 250 °C, 9 h−1 WHSV), the Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited >96% conversion of ethanol with 95% yield of ethylene, facilitated by discouraging undesired side reactions of ethanol. The role of Sr is observed to improve the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst, allowing it to function even in the presence of 94% water in the feed at operated reaction conditions, as evidenced by its stable operation in the studied period of 30 h without significant loss in catalytic activity. The rate of ethylene formation with Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 was 5.33×10 −3 molgcat −1s−1, which is higher than neat H-ZSM-5. This study highlights the production of ethylene from low concentration feedstock using a catalyst with enhanced catalytic activity even in the presence of water in the feedstock. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 Catalytic dehydration Bioethanol Ethylene Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene is a leading petrochemical and has a current market size of 176 billion USD, and it will grow to 287 billion USD by 2030 [1]. Ethylene is a key building block for the production of polyethylene, polyvinyl chloride, polystyrene, and other copolymers [2]. It also serves as the main intermediate for the production of acetaldehyde, ethylene glycol, ethylene oxide, styrene, ethyl benzene, acetic acid, ethylene dichloride, and vinyl acetate. Ethylene is primarily produced by steam cracking of the naphtha (a nonrenewable fossil fuel source); the traditional ethylene production process is among the most energy-intensive processes, leading to large carbon footprints [3]. Global concern about sustainability has urged researchers to find an alternative route for ethylene production, and renewable sources, including bioethanol, are a sustainable alternative [4–7]. In the last decade, some processes for the production of ethylene from ethanol have successfully been commercialized, like; the Atol process and the Hummingbird process. Some of the key global producers of renewable ethylene are Lummus, Chematur, Axens-Total-IFPEN, Petrobras, BP-Technip, Braskem, and Dow Chemicals. Solid acid catalysts are mainly used in these processes, which contain alumina, alumina-silica, zeolites, and heteropolyacids. The Atol process uses a ZSM-5 catalyst (ATO-201), and two adiabatic reactors are implemented in series at a relatively high temperature of 400–500 °C with 99.4% conversion and 96.4% yield. In the Hummingbird process, heteropolyacids are used as a catalyst. The Al2O3 −MgO/SiO2 catalyst is used in Braskem and Chematur processes using pure ethanol, at 300–450 °C and a WHSV of 0.23–1.17 h − 1, with >97% conversion and >92% ethylene selectivity [8]. Despite these commercial processes, other reported catalysts for catalytic dehydration of ethanol are heteropolyacids [9,10], zirconia-based catalysts [11], SBA-15 [12], ZSM-5 [13–15], zeolite Y [16], and alumina [8,17,18]. Zhan et al. reported La-P modified ZSM-5 catalyst with >96% ethylene selectivity at 300 °C and 2 h−1 WHSV using 50% ethanol as a feedstock [13]. Jiah Chee et al. reported the zeolite-Y catalyst with varying Si/Al ratios; among them, zeolite-Y having Si/Al of 80:1 showed the highest 73% conversion and 98% ethylene selectivity at a temperature of 500 °C [16]. Two pathways, direct dehydration of ethanol and through diethyl ether (DEE) intermediate for ethylene formation, are possible depending upon the reaction temperature and catalyst [19–21]. Commonly, at a low temperature, DEE is dominant; however, at a higher temperature, ethylene is selectively formed, but the much higher temperature (>450 °C) has a negative effect on ethylene selectivity due to the formation of bulky hydrocarbons and aromatics [17,22–24]. γ-A12O3 is the most studied catalyst for this application because of its stability [8,25–27], but a high concentration of ethanol and a high reaction temperature is required, which is usually >350 ℃ [28]. The use of low-concentration ethanol as feedstock offers a more sustainable route; however, catalyst stability in the presence of steam is a challenge. Rossetti et al. [29] proposed the addition of water has a drawback for catalytic activity since most of the catalyst lacks hydrothermal stability in the presence of water in the feedstock. Inducing good hydrothermal stability to the catalyst system and producing ethylene selectively at relatively low temperatures is still challenging. During catalytic dehydration of ethanol, several byproducts may form, including acetic acid, ethyl acetate, acetaldehyde, hydrocarbons (most probably C3 C4), CO2, CO, and hydrogen. Based on previous studies, ethylene formation is caused by surface acidity. The C3 C5 hydrocarbon selectivity was found to be decreased with ethanol dilution over TiO2/γ-Al2O3 (having no strong acidity) [30] but increased over SAPO-34, having strong acidity [31]. During the dehydration of ethanol, the presence of strong acidic sites eventually promote the oligomerization of ethylene. Therefore, better control over side reactions with improved ethylene selectivity is required. Improved ethylene selectivity would enhance the sustainability of the process by limiting the cost of ethylene purification. Among the catalysts reported so far for ethanol dehydration, ZSM-5 is promising in the aspect of its industrial application. However, some drawbacks are still associated with it; the major one is deactivation due to byproduct formation. Therefore, researchers are focused on modifying the catalyst to improve the catalyst stability, leading to maximum ethylene production. In the present study, we prepared a tailored H-ZSM-5 catalyst. H-ZSM-5 was modified with strontium (Sr) and nickel (Ni). The prepared catalyst was methodically studied by X-ray diffraction analysis, N2 physisorption measurements, NH3 temperature program desorption, pyridine adsorbed IR, temperature program reduction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and 27Al MAS-NMR. The dehydration of ethanol requires moderate acidity and good hydrothermal stability of the catalysts. The incorporation of Sr in H-ZSM-5 enhanced the potential of the catalyst for ethanol dehydration by increasing the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst. Further, Ni addition has improved product selectivity towards ethylene by controlling the acidity of catalysts as well as changing the electronic environment of acidic sites. The process parameters were studied, leading to selective ethanol dehydration using dilute bioethanol as a feedstock. Time-on-stream study was also performed for 30 h. The rate of ethylene formation was calculated and compared with a neat H-ZSM-5 catalyst. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials H-ZSM-5 (Si/Al molar ratio = 25–30) was purchased from ProCat India, AR grade strontium nitrate [Sr(NO₃)₂], and nickel acetate [Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O] were purchased from Alfa Aesar, and bioethanol was obtained from the in-house facility. 2.2 Catalysts preparation The Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst was prepared by modifying H-ZSM-5 catalysts. The H-ZSM-5 with a Si/Al molar ratio of 25–30 was used for catalyst preparation. Sr-ZSM-5 was prepared by ion exchange (with actual loading of 0.5 wt% as confirmed by ICP analysis). The suspension of 20 g of H-ZSM-5 was made in distilled water, and in another solution, the desired amount of Sr(NO₃)₂ was dissolved in distilled water. The Sr(NO₃)₂ solution was then added to H-ZSM-5 suspension (solid to solvent ratio = 15), and the resulting mixture was stirred for 12 h at 70 °C. The resultant mixture was centrifuged and washed thoroughly with water to remove free ions. The obtained solid was then dried overnight at 70 °C and calcined in air at 500 °C, designated as Sr-ZSM-5. Further, the Ni was impregnated over Sr-ZSM-5. To obtain a final loading of 3.3%, 2.8 g of Ni precursor, [Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O], was dissolved in distilled water as per the adsorption capacity (3 mL water per gram of catalyst). Prepared powered Sr-ZSM-5 was taken in a mortar pestle, and a solution of [Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O] was dropwise added with continuous mixing. The resulting paste was left overnight at room temperature, dried at 70 °C, and ground. The obtained solid was calcined at 500 °C with a ramping of 1 °C min−1 and held for 5 h under an air atmosphere (designated as NiO/Sr-ZSM-5). The catalyst was reduced prior to the reaction (designated as Ni/Sr-ZSM-5). The final loading of Sr and Ni was 0.5 wt% and 3.3 wt%, as confirmed by ICP analysis. The neat H-ZSM-5, Sr-ZSM-5, NiO/Sr-ZSM-5, and Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 were characterized by various techniques. 3 Characterizations The prepared catalysts were characterized in detail using different physicochemical, analytical, and spectroscopic techniques, like X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD), Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), Fourier-transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), Ammonia Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD), Pyridine adsorbed IR (Py-IR), Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR), 27Al MAS-NMR, X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS), and N2 physisorption properties. The detail of the techniques and the instruments is given in supplementary information (SI). 4 Catalytic activity setup Ethanol dehydration was carried out in a downflow fixed bed reactor having an internal diameter (ID) of 8 mm and length of 12.5 cm; the catalyst was sieved into BSS 16 mesh size and packed in the middle of the reactor between inert material (SiC) used as a diluent to minimize temperature gradient to ensure isothermal operation, diluent also helps to prevent channeling [32]. The catalyst Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 was reduced in situ under hydrogen at 350 °C prior to the reaction. The temperature of the catalyst bed was monitored by a K-type thermocouple located in the furnace, touching the outer wall of the reactor tube and inside the reactor, placed at the center of the catalyst bed. The N2 flow was maintained with a digital mass flow controller. The preheated ethanol was fed into the reactor, where the reaction was carried out at an elevated temperature ranging from 230 to 270 °C with weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) in the range of 3–12 h−1. The process diagram for ethanol dehydration (Fig. 1 ) consists of an ethanol feed tank (1), a preheater (2), a thermocouple (3), a tubular reactor (4), which consists catalyst bed (5), the furnace (6), a thermocouple (7), which controls the reaction temperature. The setup also consists of a gas-liquid separator (8), where the product stream undergoes separation. The reaction parameters were optimized to maximize ethanol conversion with ethylene selectivity. The formed gaseous and liquid products were analyzed by online GC (PerkinElmer Clarus 690) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and thermal conductivity detector (TCD). HP-PLOT Q, Heysep Q, and molecular sieve columns were used for analysis. Unreacted ethanol and hydrocarbon formed were analyzed by FID detector. Ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity among all hydrocarbons were analyzed by the formula given below. X = Ethanol conversion S = Ethylene selectivity r = Rate of ethylene formation 5 Results and discussion 5.1 Catalyst characterizations The XRD pattern of neat H-ZSM-5, Sr-ZSM-5, and Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 shows that the structure remains intact during modification of H-ZSM-5 with ion exchange and impregnation. Both Sr-ZSM-5 and Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 have shown the characteristic planes (101), (200), (501), and (303) of H-ZSM-5 at 2θ range of 7 to 30° [33]. No metal-oxide peaks are observed in the case of Sr-ZSM-5 [Fig. 2 (e)], which indicates that metal is highly dispersed on zeolite; this is in good accordance with the TEM analysis. [Fig 2] A similar observation was also reported in the previous literature by Idris A. Bakare [34]. In the case of NiO/Sr-ZSM-5 the small NiO peak is observed (Fig. S1), which is absent in the case of Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 [Fig. 2(e)]. The FT-IR spectra of prepared catalysts in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 are shown in Fig. 3 . The characteristic bands corresponding to the different OH stretching at the surface of the ZSM-5 framework are observed in the range of 3400–3800 cm−1. Also, the peak at 1640 cm−1 is assigned to OH bending present in H-ZSM-5. The peaks at 1100 and 800 cm−1 are assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of Si-O-T moiety (T=Si, Al), whereas the peaks at 1230 and 450 cm−1 are due to the external T-O (T=Si, Al) asymmetric stretching and bending respectively [35]. The band attributed to the pentacil framework of the catalyst is also seen at 545 cm−1. The HRTEM analysis of Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 clearly shows the presence of metallic Ni nanoparticles over the surface of the catalyst. Ni (111) and Ni (200) planes with d-spacing of 0.20 and 0.18 nm are observed at the 5 nm scale [Fig. 2(d)]. The TEM-EDX is shown in Fig. S2, which shows the uniform dispersion of Ni on the support. The SEM images of the prepared catalysts were obtained to identify the morphology after the modification in the neat H-ZSM-5. The obtained images reveal that morphology remains unaltered after the modification of the metals in Sr-ZSM-5 and Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 4 . The surface properties of the prepared catalysts are shown in Table 1 . BET surface area is between 280 and 325 m2/g for every catalyst; BET surface area of the catalyst follows the trend H-ZSM-5 > Sr-ZSM-5 > Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 (Table 1), indicating the decrease in the surface area with the metal incorporation in the prepared catalysts. It is due to the partial blockage of pores by the exchanged bigger Sr metal ion with protons, which is in clear agreement with the literature [34]. The BET surface area further decreased with the impregnation of Ni over the surface of the Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst. The adsorption-desorption isotherms of the neat and modified ZSM-5 show H-4 hysteresis loop (Fig. 5 ) [36]. In the case of Ni/Sr ZSM-5 catalyst, upward projection of the loop was observed at 0.9 P/Po, which indicates the formation of narrow-range mesopores that were not actually present in neat H-ZSM-5 and Sr-ZSM-5 catalysts. The number of acidic sites and relative NH3 desorption temperature are summarized in Table 1. Ammonia desorption is divided into three ranges: weak, intermediate, and strong, depending upon the desorption temperature that signifies the strength of acidic sites [37]. The ammonia desorption at a temperature below 400 °C corresponds to low to moderate acidity whereas at above 400 °C corresponds to high acidity [38]. The number of acid sites present in the solid catalyst can be calculated by the area under the desorption peaks [39,40]. According to the ammonia desorption temperature, after modification with Sr, an increase in weak acid sites is observed, and the strong acid sites are decreased, indicating the stronger acid sites become relatively weaker with the exchange of Sr, an alkaline earth metal. After Ni impregnation, followed by reduction, the acidity was reduced further. The appearance of a new strong acid site may be due to the presence of a small amount of Ni in oxide form (Fig. 6 ). However, these acidic sites are very few. The acidic sites were further evaluated by Py-IR analysis; the peak at 1540 cm−1 corresponds to Bronsted acid sites, whereas the peak at 1450 cm−1 is due to Lewis acid sites. The Bronsted acidity decreases with the modification of Sr because of the replacement of H ions by Sr ions. Further modification by Ni impregnation increases Lewis acidity due to the presence of NiO in the case of NiO/Sr-ZSM-5; however, after reduction, Lewis acidity decreases in Ni/Sr-ZSM-5, as observed in the Py-IR analysis. (Fig. S3) The presence of weak acidic sites favors ethylene formation; on the other hand, the strong acidic sites lead to the formation of several byproducts, as recalled in the introduction. The H2-TPR of NiO/Sr-ZSM-5 was performed prior to the reduction. The TPR profile for NiO/Sr-ZSM-5 is shown in Fig. S4. The main reduction peak is observed at a temperature of 300 °C which signifies the presence of bulk NiO particles [41]. The other small peaks at high temperature is due to the metal present at exchanged site. From the XRD pattern of NiO/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst, the presence of small peak for NiO indicates the formation of NiO particles on the surfaces of Sr-ZSM-5 (Fig. S1). 27Al MAS-NMR spectroscopy is used to determine the local environment of aluminum species present in the zeolite structure. Both tetrahedral (AlTd) and octahedral (AlOh) types of Al can be identified by their chemical shift. The framework tetrahedral Al (AlTd) is observed at 50–60 ppm, whereas the extra framework aluminum atoms in octahedral coordination (AlOh) are usually observed at ∼0 ppm. In the case of neat H-ZSM-5, Sr-ZSM-5, the AlTd peak is centered at 58.2 ppm and AlOh at ∼2 ppm. (Fig. 7 ). The peak for AlTd is slightly shifted to 54.4 ppm after Ni impregnation. When the catalyst is reduced under hydrogen, the peak position again shifts to 58.4 ppm, and the octahedral alumina almost vanishes, indicating that the presence of Ni helps extra framework alumina to enter the framework. The surface chemical state and composition of the Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalysts were studied by XPS. (Fig. 8 ). Si 2p XPS spectrum shows two close peaks at around 103 and 102.7 eV, corresponding to Si-O-Si and Si-O-Al, respectively [42]. O 1 s spectrum shows two peaks; the broad peak at around 532.8 eV corresponds to lattice oxygen, and 529.1 eV is due to Si-O-Ni bonds [43]. The Al 2p and Ni 3p levels partially overlap, so the spectra were deconvoluted separately. The peak at 66.58 eV corresponds to Ni0, the peak at 67.79 eV corresponds to Ni2+, and the peak at 74 eV corresponds to Al 2p [40]. The presence of Ni2+may be due to the partial oxidation during the time gap between the reduction process and the XPS analysis. Sr 3d shows two peaks corresponding to Sr 3d3/2 and Sr 3d5/2. In the Ni 2p region, six peaks were clearly observed. The peaks at 552.7 eV and 870.3 correspond to Ni0, while the peaks at 872.6 and 855.3 eV correspond to Ni 2p½ and Ni 2p3/2 of NiO respectively, accompanied by those of their corresponding satellite peaks at 879.95 and 855.53 [44,45]. The presence of metallic Ni is the main contributor to controlling the undesired side reactions during dehydration, leading to more selective ethylene production. 5.2 Significance of the work The present study reports the dehydration of bio-derived diluted ethanol into ethylene. The ethanol concentration in feed is similar to the ethanol obtained from fermentation broth. The objective of the present investigation is to design an active catalyst able to convert dilute ethanol into ethylene selectively that may improve the economic viability of the process. The catalyst durability is, of course, tested for a prolonged time, and it is found that the prepared catalyst limits byproduct formation and leads to more ethanol conversion in comparison to the neat H-ZSM-5 catalyst. 5.3 Activity testing For catalytic dehydration, different routes are proposed, one is direct dehydration into ethylene, and another is etherification to DEE followed by ethylene formation. DEE predominates at a reaction temperature of 150–200 °C, but at high temperatures, it readily converts to ethylene. The dehydration of ethanol into ethylene involves competing for products, i.e., DEE, acetic acid, acetaldehyde, ethyl acetate, methanol, C1 C4 hydrocarbon, and H2; therefore, improved selectivity would limit ethylene purification and enhance the sustainability of the process. This study is focused on the potential of using cheaper and more sustainable bio-derived feedstock for the production of ethylene. The catalytic potential of the Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst is evaluated for catalytic dehydration of bio-derived dilute ethanol into ethylene. In order to achieve the highest ethylene selectivity with maximum ethanol conversion, the dehydration was carried out at variable reaction temperatures from 230 to 250 °C and WHSV from 3 to 12 h−1; the results are reported in Fig. 10. The metals present in the catalyst impart characteristic properties to the catalysts wherein the presence of Sr makes the catalyst hydrothermally stable, which renders it more active for catalytic dehydration of dilute ethanol, and the presence of Ni discourages the side reactions during dehydration. The Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst is effective for the production of greener ethylene with a more sustainable route. 5.3.1 Effect of reaction temperature The reaction temperature primarily affects the product distribution of ethanol dehydration. Zhang et al. [46] claimed that the formation of DEE is thermodynamically favored at 150 - 200 °C, whereas ethylene is favored above 200 °C. Most of the available literature has reported dehydration at higher temperature. For easy understanding, a compendium of literature showing temperature difference (difference between reported temperature and our reaction temperature) and obtained ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity is made (Fig. 9 ); the same is discussed with references in Table S1. Fig. 10 (a) shows the effect of the reaction temperature on ethanol conversion and ethylene selectivity over the prepared catalyst (initial ethanol concentration = 6 wt% and WHSV = 6 h−1). Ethanol dehydration over Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst chiefly produces ethylene with trace amounts of CH4, H2, and other higher hydrocarbon byproducts. Thermal decomposition of ethanol forms the CH4, CO, and H2, while the CO2 and H2 are formed by water gas shift reaction by consuming the generated CO [47]. The oligomerization of ethylene produces higher hydrocarbon byproducts, viz.C3 – C4 hydrocarbons [48]. As depicted in Fig. 10(a), the ethanol conversion over Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst increases sharply with the temperature from 230 to 270 °C. At high temperatures, the ethanol molecules possess enough kinetic energy required to overcome the energy barrier. Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 possesses weak and medium acidic sites (Table 1), which resulted in higher ethylene selectivity. The effect of weak and medium acidity on ethylene production has also been evinced by Zhang et al. [49]. A lesser strong acidity plausibly diminishes ethylene oligomerization; therefore, the Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst lowers the selectivity of C3 C5 byproducts than H-ZSM-5, as observed in the TOS study (Table S4 of SI). Apart from acidity, the textural properties of the ZSM-5 catalyst also affect ethylene selectivity and conversion of ethanol. For H-ZSM-5, its high surface area and pore volume lead to deep traveling of reactant, increasing the contact time and thereby increasing the probability of side reactions [50]. Meanwhile, Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst has textural properties that may obstruct multiple adsorptions of reactant molecules, thereby minimizing the possibilities of ethylene oligomerization and other byproduct formation. The conversion of ethanol to ethylene was increased with the temperature from 230 to 250 °C. At 230 °C, the ethanol conversion was 79%, while at 250 °C, it raised to 99%, and on further increase in temperature to 270 °C, no significant increment in conversion was observed. At 230 °C, the ethylene selectivity was 99%; it remained the same at 250 °C but dropped to 97% as the temperature was increased to 270 °C [Fig. 10(a)]. The slight decrease in selectivity is due to the formation of other higher hydrocarbons at this temperature. It indicates that the higher temperature is not a suitable condition for selective ethanol dehydration. Therefore, 250 °C is considered an optimum temperature for selective ethanol dehydration. However, some of the studies have reported ethanol dehydration at a lower temperature (240 °C) [51]. Still, the other process parameters like high WHSV and low concentration ethanol as a feedstock make the current study more advantageous. 5.3.2 Effect of weight hourly space velocity The effect of WHSV was also studied; the WHSV was augmented from 3 to 12 h−1, and the gradual descent in conversion was observed because the contact time decreases with the rise in WHSV [Fig 10(b)]. With a fixed amount of catalyst, the finite number of active sites plausibly failed to have all ethanol molecules at higher WHSV; therefore, the ethanol conversion decreases with an increase in WHSV. At a WHSV of 6 h−1, the ethanol conversion was 99.3% with a selectivity of 99.6%, and it remained almost the same with the increase in the WHSV to 9 h−1, but the conversion was decreased to 95 with a further increase in the WHSV to 12 h−1. Therefore 9 h−1 is considered an optimum WHSV for the process. 5.3.3 Effect of ethanol concentration The concentration of ethanol was varied to evaluate the potentiality of catalytic ethanol dehydration over Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst. Ethanol derived from biomass mostly contains water and is purified via azeotropic distillation, which is energy-intensive. Direct conversion of bio-derived dilute ethanol to ethylene is an effective process since it eliminates the purification step. The catalytic dehydration of bio-derived ethanol over Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst with varied ethanol concentration (6 - 70 wt%) is depicted in Table S2. It is observed that the ethanol conversion dropped with increased ethanol concentration in the feedstock from 6 wt% to 70 wt%. Unlike ethanol conversion, no remarkable change has been seen in ethylene selectivity with varied ethanol concentrations in the feedstock. It has been observed that the prepared catalyst is more particularly active for the dehydration of dilute ethanol, which is one of the advantages of the present work. 5.3.4 Time-on-stream study At optimized reaction conditions (temp. = 250 °C, WHSV = 9 h−1, N2 flow rate = 10 mL min−1), the time-on-stream study was performed for 6 h with H-ZSM-5, Sr-ZSM-5, and Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 and the results are compared in Table S3. Further, the complete product distribution with H-ZSM-5 and Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalysts at optimum reaction conditions is tabulated (Table S4). The product distribution shows that Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst is better for selective ethanol dehydration than the H-ZSM-5 catalyst. The addition of a small amount of Ni controls the undesired secondary reactions for heavier olefins formation, which results in improved ethylene selectivity without compromising the ethanol conversion. The Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst also increases the rate of formation of ethylene. It was observed that the initial rate of formation was 5.33×10 −3 molgcat −1s−1 with both the catalyst, but in the case of H-ZSM-5 the rate of formation of ethylene decreases rapidly with time, whereas the decrease is lesser in the case of Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 (Fig. 11 ). After 10 h on stream, the rate of formation was found to be 5.28×10 −3 molgcat −1s−1 with Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 whereas it decreased to 4.75×10 −3 molgcat −1s−1 with neat H-ZSM-5. The coke deposition at the surface of the catalyst was also studied. Coking occurs mainly due to oligomerization and polymerization; the main issue of coking in the conversion of ethanol to ethylene is the ethylene itself, which oligomerizes and eventually turns into coke formation [52]. The strong acidic site on the solid acid catalysts is the main contributor to coke formation with the secondary reactions of produced ethylene. The coke formation can be suppressed by either controlling the strong acid sites or reducing the residence time, but that lowers the reactivity of the catalyst [53,54]. Here, the Ni reduces strong acid sites, changes their electronic environment, and therefore suppresses the byproduct formation (Table S4). The Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 is very active with high conversion and ethylene selectivity. The increase in selectivity achieved may also make the ethylene separation/purification process easier. The carbon deposition on the catalyst during the reaction was estimated by TGA; it is clear from the analysis that the Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 has lesser coke deposition in comparison to the neat H-ZSM-5 catalyst. Up to 200 °C, the weight loss is due to adsorbed water. The weight loss at a temperature range of 400–600 °C is due to carbon deposition; the weight loss is less in the case of Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst after 10 h of reaction (Fig. S5). The spent catalysts were also characterized by XRD, and it has been observed that there is a peak shift to a higher value in the case of spent H-ZSM-5; this points out the slight lattice contraction caused by dealumination. (Fig. S6). No such changes are observed in spent Ni/Sr-ZSM-5, indicating that Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 is more stable. The catalyst Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 was active for the dehydration of ethanol to ethylene even up to 30 h, as revealed by the TOS study (Fig. 12 ). The conversion was ∼96%, and the ethylene selectivity was ∼98%. The characterization of catalysts reveals that Ni increases the catalytic activity of the catalyst by suppressing the undesired byproduct formation, leading to more selective ethylene production. The selectivity achieved here can decrease the cost of ethylene separation. When complete ethanol conversion with 100% selectivity of the product is achieved, ethylene can be purified by the easy separation of water. The good hydrothermal stability also made the catalyst stable for a longer time. The hydrothermal stability caused by Sr ions was investigated by treating the ZSM-5 and Sr-ZSM-5 with steam; the detailed procedure is given in SI. After steam treatment, the catalysts were characterized by NH3-TPD, and observed that the NH3 desorption decreases in both the catalysts, but the decrease is more in the case of steam-treated H-ZSM-5 [H-ZSM-5 (ST)] than steam-treated Sr-ZSM-5 [Sr-ZSM-5 (ST)]. Also, the peak maxima for weak acidic sites decrease to a lower temperature in the case of H-ZSM-5 (ST), indicating partial dealumination (Fig. S7, S8), a similar phenomenon was observed by Fijisawa et al. [55]. 5.4 Mechanism of ethanol dehydration In zeolites, the mechanism of ethanol dehydration is a little complicated; it depends on the type of active sites and the strength of active sites involved in the dehydration. We proposed a possible mechanism for ethanol dehydration, as shown in Scheme S1. The ethanol dehydration to ethylene can occur on both Bronsted acid and Lewis acid sites. In the detailed mechanism occurring on Bronsted acid sites, the proton of Bronsted acid migrates to the O atom of ethanol, and one H atom of ethanol bonds with the neighboring electronegative skeleton O atom of the zeolite. Ethoxy groups will proceed with β-H elimination to form ethylene, accompanied by recovery of Bronsted acid sites [6]. (Scheme S1a) In the dehydration mechanism on Lewis acid sites, first, the O atom of ethanol is attached to the skeleton Al atom of zeolite that behaves as a Lewis acid site. The ethanol can dehydrate directly to ethylene with the removal of water, or another ethanol molecule is again attached, leading to the formation of diethyl ether (DEE). That can further be converted to ethanol and an ethylene molecule. (Scheme S1b) We assume that the direct dehydration of ethanol to ethylene is more prominent on Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 as no DEE formation is observed at optimized reaction conditions. 6 Conclusions The present protocol demonstrates a potential catalytic process for the conversion of bio-derived ethanol (a cheaper feedstock) for effective ethylene production. The incorporation of Sr and Ni generates an efficient catalyst for selective ethylene production from ethanol, which ensures the highest conversion at 250 °C and WHSV of 9 h−1. The Sr improves hydrothermal stability, whereas Ni loading on Sr-ZSM-5 plays an important role in selective ethylene formation by minimizing the byproduct formation. Overall, Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 has proved to be a viable catalyst that holds good catalytic activity even in the presence of water in the feedstock to produce ethylene with >98% selectivity and ∼96% conversion even after 30 h on stream. The rate of formation of ethylene is higher for Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 than for H-ZSM-5. The catalyst system of the present study provides a wide scope in dealing with bio-derived ethanol, having plenty of water for the selective production of olefins. coredata.dc:description: Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst was synthesized with tuned acidity and improved hydrothermal stability desired for the dehydration of dilute ethanol. Operating conditions were established to maximize the ethylene selectivity from ethanol dehydration by controlling side reactions, using 6% aqueous ethanol as a model feedstock for fermenter broth. Detailed characterization data of the catalyst reveals that Ni in the catalyst is responsible for the enhanced, near quantitative ethylene selectivity at optimum reaction conditions (temperature of 250 °C, 9 h−1 WHSV), the Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited >96% conversion of ethanol with 95% yield of ethylene, facilitated by discouraging undesired side reactions of ethanol. The role of Sr is observed to improve the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst, allowing it to function even in the presence of 94% water in the feed at operated reaction conditions, as evidenced by its stable operation in the studied period of 30 h without significant loss in catalytic activity. The rate of ethylene formation with Ni/Sr-ZSM-5 was 5.33×10 −3 molgcat −1s−1, which is higher than neat H-ZSM-5. This study highlights the production of ethylene from low concentration feedstock using a catalyst with enhanced catalytic activity even in the presence of water in the feedstock.
coredata.dc:title: Ni and Sr modified ZSM-5 catalyst with enhanced catalytic activity for selective dehydration of bio-derived ethanol to ethylene
